utterances: Yes.
No, she did not.
I do not believe that she would have said it that way.
She may have said that were more stories written that were favorable to Obama, and I think there've been some objective studies that showed that in all forms of media.
But it goes to the question of intent, and I don't think that there are any legitimate journalists who were doing news stories that were trying to sway voters in one way or another.
Now, that's an argument that people will not accept.
But I - as a journalist, I don't believe that we do that.
And I just add that when look back and you realize that, you know, the winners often get better coverage than the losers, is it possible (Laughing) there's a reason for that?
Brett, how do you respond to that?
If you're making a story that makes Obama look good and McCain look bad, by definition, you're trying to get Obama elected.
No, no, no. I don't think that's true at all.
If you report what someone does and as a result, one candidate looks better than the other, that's not necessarily saying that you intend for that person to win.
Well, that'sâ€¦
I think that's an unfair assessment of what journalists do.

And I think you might want to go back and reread the ombudsman column, because I'm not sure that's - you portrayed it accurately, Brett, but of course you're entitled to your opinion, and you even got a follow-up question, (Laughing) so thanks very much for the phone call.
(Soundbite of laughter)
We have a big problem with electricity here, Balumay says.
There's no power in Bukavu.
We're talking with Dan Froomkin, the White House Watch blog for WashingtonPost.com and deputy editor of NeimanWatchdog.org, and also with us, Sam Fulwood, who's a contributor to TheRoot.com.
You're listening to Talk of the Nation from NPR News.
Jerry's with us, Jerry calling from Grand Rapids, Michigan.
Hi, I'd like to respond to a couple of callers previously who asked your panel about why the presidents don't respond to follow-up questions.
I guess my question is if the news briefing and the - or the press conference is not the place to show accountability, then where do we hold these people accountable?

And furthermore, if they're not going to give the reporters candid, straight answers, then what's the purpose of someone like me watching this news conference if I'm not going to get any pertinent information?
Good questions.
What do you think?
What do you think, Dan?
Well, I think we'll have a lot more to say about this on Monday.
I think that what you'll see there is a real sense of what kind of questions the press will pursue and how President Obama will answer them.
He has - I mean, he did - he's surprising sometimes.
I mean, certainly in those interviews on Tuesday, you know, when he actually said he screwed up was a kind of a shocking, jaw-dropping admission from a president.
So, it's possible he - and he's also a very, very smart, thoughtful guy who thinks on his feet, and so I think we may get substantive answers.
I think we should expect it, and if we don't, we should very disappointed, and we should make that very clear.
What the president is planning - I mean, I don't know what he's going to say, but it's clear that he is selling his economic stimulus package.
And he wants to get before the public, he wants to have people see and hear him talk about a national issue, and the reporters basically will be props for him to be able to say what he wants.
So, the caller's asking, why should he watch?
He should watch to sort of get a better understanding of how the president sells his message.
Well, also this president - I'm not sure unlike the others - but this president in particular seemed to run saying, hold me to a higher standard.
I'm going to demand it of myself.
I'm going to demand it of my members of my Cabinet.
You should demand it of me, too.
Yeah, and I think, actually, in this case, the why questions are going to be the most important - not what do you think we should do, but why do you think we should do it?
You know, why are you so sure that this is the way to go?
Why are you sure - how did you conclude that this is the right balance between, you know, short-term stimulus and long-term strategy?
Who are you listening to?
And he said to CNN's Anderson Cooper that's he's - you know, he's not - economy is not one of his strong suits.
So, who is he listening to?
How does he decide among them when they disagree?
I mean - so, right now, I mean, even though there's a lot of confidence in Obama, I don't think anybody's ready to just sort of accept this on faith.
As a journalist, I want to sound an alarm of skepticism, not cynicism, about what the president was saying when he said, hold me accountable.
He was trying to get elected.
Governing is a totally different game.
Jerry, thanks very much for the call.
We appreciate it.
And we will all listen with interest on Monday night when the president holds his first primetime news conference since taking office.
Our thanks to Dan Froomkin who writes the White House Watch blog for WashingtonPost.com, with us from member station WAMU here in Washington, D.C.
Our thanks as well to Sam Fulwood, a contributor to TheRoot.com, here with us in studio 3A.
Up next - the Postal Service says it may cut one day of mail delivery per week.
What do you think?
I'm Neal Conan.
Talk of the Nation, NPR News.
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Mike Pesca in Washington.
Neal Conan is away.
These five days between votes in Iowa and New Hampshire are kind of a political Mardi Gras.
The crews of Clinton, Obama, Romney, McCain - they're the hottest tickets in town.
And we, the voters, are drunk on a hurricane of attack ads and poll numbers.
But wait a minute and take a step back.
Put down the beads because we are engaging in a sobering process.
On February 5th, Super Duper Tsunami Tuesday, more of us will be asked earlier than ever: tell, pick a party nominee for president.
And how do we do that?
I mean, really, the surges in the poll suggest that a lot of people are being swept up in a wave.
Is that it?
Are we that impressionable?
How do we, as voters, really decide?
Later on, we'll talk about the broken campaign promises that broke our hearts.
But first, when it comes to voting - what is it?
Is it issues?
Is it character?
Or do we just vote on the cut of the candidate's jib?
Give it some thought and join the conversation.
Tell us how you make up your mind.
Our number here in Washington is 800-989-8255.
Our e-mail address is talk@npr.org.
You can also comment on our blog, it's at npr.org/blogofthenation.
Joining us with one view on how voters decide is Ann Mack.
She is director of trend spotting for the advertising agency JWT.
Hi, Ann.
Hi.
Trend spotting - ooh, that's a cool title.
Thank you.
What's the trend in how voters are deciding, and is it really a trend?
Well, voters decide based on a couple of things, primarily rational and emotional triggers.
But right now, they are going with their emotions; that's why candidates are throwing around the word change so frequently following Barack's win in Iowa.
Now, when you say right now they're going with their emotions, do you mean the ones that based on purely or mostly intellectual means they've already made up their minds?
To an extent.
Some people are weighing the pros and the cons and the assets and liabilities and the baggage that these candidates carry with them, and then they'll make a decision.
But quite frequently, they'll go to the polls, cast their ballot, and then post-rationalize their behavior by talking about the issues.
The marriage debate created a big national spotlight.
Now those with other concerns hope to nudge their issues onto center stage - among them, retired nurse David Moyer.
He's 72 years old.
Balumay sells men's shirts, liquor, transistor radios - whatever he you can buy Cheaply in Kampala and Dubai, he imports here.
(Speaking foreign language)
The problems begin when the goods arrive here in Congo, he says.
The authorities demand tax.
They harass us a lot.
Balumay, who's 32 years old, has never cast a ballot in an election.
In fact, there's never been a democratic election in the Congo in his entire lifetime.

He says he's excited about voting, and he hopes that under an elected government the constant demands for bribes by soldiers, government officials and police will come to an end and the process of rebuilding this shattered country can begin.
Jason Beaubien, NPR News, Bukavu.
This is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Debbie Elliott.
In the southern Gaza Strip today, there was a mix of frenzy and joy as Palestinians crossed into Egypt through a border checkpoint now under Palestinian control.
The Palestinian Authority took over the crossing yesterday, following an agreement brokered by the US and European Union.
Now for the first time, Palestinians have gained partial control of one of their international borders.
NPR's Eric Westervelt has our report from Rafah in Gaza.
(Soundbite of voices; vehicle horn)
In the early afternoon, the first busload of Palestinian passed into Egypt.
There was frustration and confusion.
The border was open for just four hours today.

Palestinian authorities hope to expand hours soon, but today, Gazans pushed and tussled, dismayed at the disorganization and long lines as Palestinian security officials struggled to screen passports in a timely manner, but most Palestinians still called it a happy day.
For nearly four decades of Israeli military occupation, they point out, it was common to wait for hours, even days, for Israeli permission to cross.
Sixty-five-year-old Mohammad Shardon(ph) is a lemon and orange farmer from Jabaliya.
He says it's his first time traveling to Egypt in more than a decade.
(Through Translator) God willing, Gaza will not be a jail anymore.
We hope that economically and psychologically it will be much better now.
Many ordinary Gazans such Shardon went out of their way to express gratitude to US Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice whose personal involvement earlier this month helped broker the deal.
(Through Translator) We really thank the Americans and Minister Rice for solving this issue.
I thank America for finally understanding our problems and working to solve them.
Palestinians see this partial border control as a key move towards self-rule in Gaza in the wake of Israel's unilateral withdrawal this summer.
A Palestinian security official says males between 18 and 40 years of age are given more scrutiny at the border.
Israeli officials worry that Islamic militants will exploit the crossing to smuggle weapons and extremists to attack the Jewish state.
Under the deal, Israel gets a real-time computer and video feed of the border to a joint EU and Israeli-Palestinian situation room.
EU monitors, who are still arriving, were mostly out of sight today.
(Soundbite of monitoring equipment)
